an10.87:1.1: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants concerning the mendicant Kalandaka:
an10.87:2.1: “Firstly, a mendicant raises disciplinary issues and doesn’t praise the settlement of disciplinary issues.
an10.87:2.2: This quality doesn’t conduce to warmth, respect, esteem, harmony, and unity.
an10.87:3.1: Furthermore, a mendicant doesn’t want to train, and doesn’t praise taking up the training. …
an10.87:4.1: Furthermore, a mendicant has bad desires, and doesn’t praise getting rid of desires. …
an10.87:5.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is irritable, and doesn’t praise getting rid of anger. …
an10.87:6.1: Furthermore, a mendicant denigrates others, and doesn’t praise getting rid of denigration. …
an10.87:7.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is devious, and doesn’t praise getting rid of deviousness. …
an10.87:8.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is deceitful, and doesn’t praise getting rid of deceitfulness. …
an10.87:9.1: Furthermore, a mendicant doesn’t pay attention to the teachings, and doesn’t praise attending to the teachings. …
an10.87:10.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is not in retreat, and doesn’t praise retreat. …
an10.87:11.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is inhospitable to their spiritual companions, and doesn’t praise hospitality.
an10.87:11.2: This quality doesn’t conduce to warmth, respect, esteem, harmony, and unity.
an10.87:12.1: Even though a mendicant such as this might wish:
an10.87:12.2: ‘If only my spiritual companions would honor, respect, esteem, and venerate me!’ Still they don’t honor, respect, esteem, and venerate them.
an10.87:12.4: Because their sensible spiritual companions see that they haven’t given up those bad unskillful qualities.
an10.87:13.1: Suppose a wild colt was to wish:
an10.87:13.2: ‘If only the humans would put me in a thoroughbred’s place, feed me a thoroughbred’s food, and give me a thoroughbred’s grooming.’ Still the humans wouldn’t put them in a thoroughbred’s place, feed them a thoroughbred’s food, or give them a thoroughbred’s grooming.
an10.87:13.4: Because sensible humans see that they haven’t given up their tricks, bluffs, ruses, and feints.
an10.87:13.5: In the same way, even though a mendicant such as this might wish:
an10.87:13.6: ‘If only my spiritual companions would honor, respect, esteem, and venerate me!’ Still they don’t honor, respect, esteem, and venerate them.
an10.87:13.8: Because their sensible spiritual companions see that they haven’t given up those bad unskillful qualities.
an10.87:14.1: Next, a mendicant doesn’t raise disciplinary issues and praises the settlement of disciplinary issues.
an10.87:14.2: This quality conduces to warmth, respect, esteem, harmony, and unity.
an10.87:15.1: Furthermore, a mendicant wants to train, and praises taking up the training. …
an10.87:16.1: Furthermore, a mendicant has few desires, and praises getting rid of desires. …
an10.87:17.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is not irritable, and praises getting rid of anger. …
an10.87:18.1: Furthermore, a mendicant doesn’t denigrate others, and praises getting rid of denigration. …
an10.87:19.1: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t devious, and praises getting rid of deviousness. …
an10.87:20.1: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t deceitful, and praises getting rid of deceitfulness. …
an10.87:21.1: Furthermore, a mendicant pays attention to the teachings, and praises attending to the teachings. …
an10.87:22.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is in retreat, and praises retreat. …
an10.87:23.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is hospitable to their spiritual companions, and praises hospitality.
an10.87:23.2: This quality conduces to warmth, respect, esteem, harmony, and unity.
an10.87:24.1: Even though a mendicant such as this might never wish:
an10.87:24.2: ‘If only my spiritual companions would honor, respect, esteem, and venerate me!’ Still they honor, respect, esteem, and venerate them.
an10.87:24.4: Because their sensible spiritual companions see that they’ve given up those bad unskillful qualities.
an10.87:25.1: Suppose a fine thoroughbred never wished:
an10.87:25.2: ‘If only the humans would put me in a thoroughbred’s place, feed me a thoroughbred’s food, and give me a thoroughbred’s grooming.’ Still the humans would put them in a thoroughbred’s place, feed them a thoroughbred’s food, and give them a thoroughbred’s grooming.
an10.87:25.4: Because sensible humans see that they’ve given up their tricks, bluffs, ruses, and feints.
an10.87:26.1: In the same way, even though a mendicant such as this might never wish:
an10.87:26.2: ‘If only my spiritual companions would honor, respect, esteem, and venerate me!’ Still they honor, respect, esteem, and venerate them.
an10.87:26.4: Because their sensible spiritual companions see that they’ve given up those bad unskillful qualities.”
